Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Salt Rock Microstructure and Deformation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Salt rock is used for secure storage of oil, high-pressure gas, and nuclear waste because of its ability to creep and form barriers to gas and fluid flow. However, creep processes near subsurface storage facilities can lead to crack debonding, opening, closure and rebonding that compromise the integrity of flow barriers and stability of engineered structures. Mathematical descriptions of cracking and healing are incompletely developed. This award will support fundamental rock physics and mechanics research to link deformation by crack debonding, opening and rebonding to microstructures and mechanical variables that govern the time-dependent behavior of salt rock over geological space and time scales. Deformation of salt occurs rapidly at laboratory conditions making it a good analog to study damage and healing in other crystalline materials and porous media. Project findings are expected to advance quantitative relations enabling accurate modeling and prediction of behaviors in engineering projects. The work will advance fundamental understanding of cracking and healing in other rocks that deform by the same processes, especially around earthquake faults and zones of induced seismicity. The team of geoscience and engineering researchers will collaborate with other programs to broaden the participation of women and other under-represented groups in research and engineering.

Most continuum damage models for salt are based on the concept of dilatancy boundary, and do not account for crack-induced anisotropy of elastic properties. Micro-mechanics and homogenization principles were successfully employed to model salt rock elastoplastic behavior, but were not used to test scale invariance of microstructure to transitions in deformation regimes. The goal of this project is to link salt deformation regimes and rheological behaviors with the density and orientation distribution of microstructures. Deformation regimes at the scale of a Representative Elementary Volume will be decomposed into independent processes (e.g., cracking), each related to different microstructure descriptors (e.g., grain aspect ratio). Macroscopic thermodynamic variables will be formally related to the microstructure descriptors to test the space and time scale invariance of transition points in deformation regimes. Specific research objectives are to: (1) Identify topological components and subcomponents of salt microstructure; (2) Determine the energy cost of intra- and inter-granular crack debonding, opening, closure and rebonding; (3) Compute energy thresholds associated with transitions between deformation regimes at the grain and REV scales; (4) Test the time and scale dependence of microstructure organization during transitions; (5) Design rock salt microstructural systems that optimize healing properties in subsurface storage environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Modern society employs engineered facilities for storage of energy resources and waste that are under the ground. A common facility type is an underground cavern cut into salt-rock that is used to store hydrocarbons, high-pressure gas, and hazardous waste. Caverns that cut into natural salt rock in the subsurface can be ideal for storage of liquids and gas because salt rock will flow very-slowly (creep) and self-seal over engineering time scales. During construction and in some cases over the expected lifetime, however, these facilities can lose their sealing capacity and even collapse due to creep of the salt. Mechanical behavior of salt rock has been studied for some time; however, numerical modeling techniques and computing capabilities have greatly advanced, allowing for more detailed and accurate mathematical descriptions of salt rock behavior and cavern stability. This collaborative project between materials geoscientists at Texas A&M University and geotechnical civil engineers at Georgia Institute of Technology investigates the mechanical behavior of salt rock at conditions appropriate to underground caverns. This is achieved by integrating laboratory deformation experiments and microscopy studies (TAMU), to document deformation processes, with theoretical development of continuum damage-mechanics models (GT) that address directional-dependence of mechanical properties induced by grain-scale cracks and by the development(evolution) of pore networks.

For the experimental and microscopy studies at Texas A&M University, two endmember types of synthetic salt rock were produced for testing. A synthetic wet, granular, porous salt-rock was produced to represent backfill material used to seal caverns for storage, and a synthetic dry, non-porous, recrystallized salt-rock was produced to represent the natural salt-rock in underground formations. Experimental deformation tests employed varied loading techniques to explore macroscopic elastic and plastic flow behaviors, creep relaxation, and anelasticity (time-dependent elasticity), and to infer the microscopic mechanisms of deformation.  Microscopy studies of sequentially deformed samples and samples with specific loading histories were conducted to document occurrence and operation of grain-scale processes including grain boundary crack opening and frictional sliding, intragranular plasticity and cracking, sliding by water-assisted diffusion, crack healing, neocrystallization, and pore collapse. Findings on mechanical behavior, microstructure geometry (fabrics) and evolution, and relative role of fundamental grain-scale processes were used by the Georgia Tech engineers to guide their model development and provide tests of model predictions. Application tests of the resulting microstructure-enriched continuum damage mechanics models and joint-enriched Finite Element Methods demonstrate improved ability to design and analyze large scale storage facilities.

Broader Impacts

This project involved a new collaboration between faculty and students of the Department of Geology & Geophysics at Texas A&M University and faculty and students of the School of Civil and Environmental Engineering at Georgia Tech, bringing together unique expertise from the geosciences and engineering to advance our understanding of natural systems perturbed by anthropogenic changes in the subsurface. At Texas A&M the project supported doctoral research by a Ph.D. student in Geology (degree awarded 2019) who is now a postdoctoral scientist at Stanford University working on chemo-mechanical processes in unconventional-reservoir shale rocks. It also provided the opportunity for an undergraduate student to carry out a senior research project in materials testing for her B.S. degree in Geophysics at Texas A&M, and to go on to the University of Alabama for a M.S. in Geophysics; she is now employed in the petroleum industry. This project required improvements to our laboratory research facility, particularly the addition of a new capability to work with water sensitive materials in a dry environment during sample preparation for both experiments and microscopy. This capability will be available to others for research and teaching activities.

Another significant impact of the research on salt-rocks at low effective stress is the contribution to understanding semibrittle deformation (deformation by coupled brittle and crystal-plastic micro-scale processes) in other geologic settings. In particular, this study can be used to better understand natural deformation behavior deeper in the silicate crust where elevated temperatures and fluid pressures exist. Salt rocks may be viewed as a model material to study the fundamental microscopic processes leading to macroscopic mechanical recovery in cracked-crystalline and porous-granular materials, which can bring new insight into geomechanics, geology, and material sciences. Knowledge gained from study of the deformation microprocesses and the development of microstructure-enriched continuum damage mechanics models for salt rock is applicable to modeling earthquake phenomena because cyclic loading, fatigue, failure and healing processes along seismic faults are similar to those encountered in geological storage systems.
